newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Australia, Indonesia agree on marine boundary.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Australia, Indonesia agree on marine boundary.

text.p: Indonesia and Australia have agreed on the maritime boundary between them, the Australian government said on Friday.
"The agreement effectively finalises the maritime boundaries between Australia and Indonesia," Foreign Affairs Minister Alexander Downer said in a statement.
"The agreement will now be submitted to the Australian and Indonesian governments for formal approval," he said.
Officials had agreed to the three outstanding unsettled boundaries:
--The water column and seabed boundary between Christmas Island, in the Indian Ocean, and Java.
--A western extension of the seabed boundary previously agreed to near Australia's Ashmore and Cartier islands.
--The water column boundary between continental Australia and Indonesia.
The water column boundary applies to anything swimming in the water, whereas the seabed boundary relates to anything on or under the seabed.

They can differ because it is convenient for the seabed boundary to follow geographical features, such as a trenchline, while the water boundary is best kept in straight lines for ships navigating on the surface.
